{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3594997,"name":"","username":"itamar4590","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/itamar4590/{size}/227494_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-17T18:28:12.539Z","cooked":"

I thought about using delrin or ptfe for the contact points on a 2910 style telescoping arm, but making contact with bearings intreduced some unwanted problems and complexity. I was thinking about using delrin or ptfe blocks. Is it anyh good? Are there any good example for those types of things?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-04-17T18:28:12.539Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":20,"reads":261,"readers_count":260,"score":152.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":499614,"topic_slug":"materials-for-elevator-telescoping-arm-contact-points","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62307,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4590 cad/mechanics"},"post_url":"/t/materials-for-elevator-telescoping-arm-contact-points/499614/1","custom_user_title":"4590 cad/mechanics","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3595021,"name":"Phil Szymanowski","username":"Cyberphil","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cyberphil/{size}/161083_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-17T18:56:13.767Z","cooked":"

Take a look at team 25’s slide elevators over the years. They have historically used 1x1 tubing with Delrin slide blocks in lieu of bearing setups you see most teams running now.

103 and 25 build near identical versions of this elevator in 2011, both with decent success. The benefits are it is probably a bit lighter construction than elevators with roller bearings, and if you are custom-making your own elevator (no COTS) it’s probably easier than making your own roller bearing blocks. Drawbacks are it has significantly more resistance, especially when loaded one way or another, and if things are not very well aligned it has a tendency to bind where a roller bearing elevator would never.

We ran some what of a hybrid in 2023 with bearings for up down and delran? spacers as sliding blocks.

image1463×1049 104 KB

LigerBots 2877 FRC OpenAlliance Build Thread 2023!

Arm

CAD: Onshape

  • 3 Stage cascading Elevator.
  • CADed and manufactured in house by students
  • Dimensions:
    • Stage zero: 3 in (1/8in)
    • Stage one: 2 in (1/16in)
    • Stage two: 1.5 in (1/16in)
  • Neo with a 10:1 Reduction.
  • Used 1/8th rope for cascade, we tried thinner rope but it kept breaking.
  • Made with Mill and CNC router

We first did it in 2022 at a smaller scale:

Which CF Springs for pinkarm bot?

In 2022 we used 4 bearing in the side of more force(forward/back) and slider plates for the other 2 sides.

PXL_20230114_141901936.MP3024×4032 434 KB

PXL_20230114_141915575.MP4032×3024 517 KB

(Orange 3D printed part was for a dry fit test)
